is up=
dated. Is there anyone who had the same problem before? It is 
probably bec=
ause I decided to install VS2008 to try it and stuff.. 
There are files wit=
hout this issue? Probably a missing service pack or 
something. 

I labeled=
 it as explosion incorrectly. It is how to scale the 
coordinates for the 4=
D HyperNEAT part of the CPPN down to [-1 .. 1] 
without making large change=
s look insignificant to it. 

But individuals with lots of cells should be =
also similar genetically. 
I will try a couple of ways to query CTRNN Hyper=
NEAT substrates out of 
the cells and activate some kind of muscles..

ust uploaded a screenshot of the program here:

s.

 coordinates are there once development is done?

> --- In nea=
t@yahoogroups.com, "petar_chervenski" <petar_chervenski@>
> wrote:

exe".

d 
after 
> > development. But how should I deal with the "coordinate explo=
sion" 
> > then? Because I don't really know how big the phenotype can get.=
 
There 
> > is some limit, of course, but I am looking for an elegant way =
to 
solve 
> > the problem. Rescaling to [-1..1] is more of a hack than a 
=
solution.
> > 
> > Peter
> > 
> > --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Kenneth Sta=
nley" <kstanley@> wrote:
> > >
> > > Peter, sounds interesting.  I'll be in=
terested to see the 
executable
> > > version to get an intuition of the ki=
nds of structures your 
method
> > > creates.  
> > > 
> > > About the link=
s:  My guess is that it's best to compute their 
values
> > > at the end of=
 development since that is the "final geometry" of 
the
> > > brain that I =
believe makes sense to exploit.  In other words, it 
> > gives
> > > the br=
ain the opportunity to exploit the changes occur over
> > > development.  O=
therwise, it would seem that those changes and 
the
> > > genes that encode=
 them are not really being used for any 
purpose.
> > > 
> > > ken
> > > 
>=
 > > --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "petar_chervenski" 
<petar_chervenski@>
>=
 > > wrote:
> > > >
> > > > Hi all!
> > > > 
> > > > For those of you who a=
re not familiar with this particular 
> > subject, it 
> > > > is about phy=
sical object evolution with CPPNs. There are some 
> > problems 
> > > > wh=
en trying to use CPPNs directly to map onto 2/3D objects 
with 
> > > > fin=
ite, though variable (among individuals) size. I am 
> > particularly
> > >=
 interested in this issue because it also holds the key to the 
> > > > aut=
omatic generation of HyperNEAT substrates as well. And 
perhaps 
> > it 
> =
> > > may open up new ways to have content generation in games, too. 
And 
=
> > > > Artificial Life, of course.
> > > > 
> > > > I remember that Ken su=
ggested that animal morphologies and 
such 
> > things 
> > > > may be easi=
er to describe in higher dimensional space and then 
> > mapped 
> > > > ba=
ck to 2D/3D, just like in HyperNEAT. Day after day I was 
trying 
> > to 
>=
 > > > find such a higher-dimensional description of something that 
has 
>=
 > > > limbs, joints, all with variable numbers and size. Even in the 
> > =
most 
> > > > simplistic 2D case, I never got even close to such an elegant=
 
> > > > solution. 
> > > > 
> > > > Suppose I want to have a 2D creature =
with rectangular limbs. 
But 
> > how 
> > > > many of them is unknown. How=
 they are connected - too. A limb 
is  
> > > > represented as position in =
2D and width/height and an angle of 
> > > > orientation. This makes 5D spa=
ce in which I have to query all 
> > possible 
> > > > things and ask the C=
PPN if there is a limb or not. Sounds too 
> > > > expensive, and more, eve=
n if I do that, there are 
> > > > algorithmic/implementation issues that a=
re just too hard. 
> > > > 
> > > > The problem I had is, actually, that I =
missed the fact that a 
CPPN 
> > is 
> > > > an infinite mathematical desc=
ription of the phenotype. Any use 
of 
> > a 
> > > > CPPN involves approxi=
mating the phenotype with some kind of 
level 
> > of 
> > > > detail. The =
CPPN makes no difference if I use it for 16x16 
visual 
> > > > substrate o=
r 65536x65536, for example (note: I mean not in 
> > phenotype 
> > > > eva=
luation). So there must be a way to have such level of 
detail 
> > > > sca=
ling in animal morphologies as well. 
> > > > 
> > > > So I went back to th=
e cellular growth approach, looking for 
what I 
> > > > missed before. The=
 biggest unsolved problem with my previous 
> > system is 
> > > > that coo=
rdinates may grow to infinite and the activation 
functions 
> > are 
> > >=
 > actually best suited to work in [-1..1] substrates (given the 
fact 
> >=
 I 
> > > > have fixed CPPN weight range and mutation powers). Plus, the 
C=
PPN 
> > is 
> > > > requeried on each cell on each timestep in the process=
 of 
> > development. 
> > > > Too expensive and as the phenotype gets bigg=
er, development 
slows 
> > down 
> > > > to a rate that is not acceptable.=
 And more, it is not clear 
how 
> > > > scaling could work if I want to, s=
ay, have the same object, 
the 
> > same 
> > > > shape, much bigger, but t=
he cell size and the coordinate 
frames - 
> > > > still fixed. Something w=
as terribly wrong with that model. But 
I 
> > think 
> > > > I have finall=
y found a solution! Or at least something very 
close 
> > to 
> > > > it.
=
> > > > 
> > > > The CPPN already encodes all the development of a phenotyp=
e 
with 
> > any 
> > > > precision via composing coordinate frames. A whol=
e phenotype 
with 
> > all 
> > > > its patterns with infinite (well at lea=
st huge) precision can 
be 
> > fit 
> > > > into just the patch of [-1 .. =
1] in Cartesian space. Assume I 
will 
> > be 
> > > > talking about 2D spa=
ce only for simplicity. That patch [-1 .. 
1] 
> > in 
> > > > both X and Y=
 I call "the Egg". 
> > > > 
> > > > The first approach I took with the ide=
a of the egg was too 
simple, 
> > but 
> > > > it is interesting to know a=
bout. After the CPPN "paints" the 
egg 
> > with 
> > > > cell color and st=
uff, then it is re-queried again, this time 
the 
> > > > outputs are 2D ve=
ctors. The magnitude of these vectors was re-
> > scaled 
> > > > to be wit=
hin [0 .. MAX_DISTANCE]. So the entire phenotype 
building 
> > > > procedu=
re became very simple - first build the egg, then send 
each 
> > > > cell =
where its vector points. Well that looks so ugly in 
practice, 
> > > > wit=
h empty holes and.. eh.. forget that! This is not anything 
more 
> > > > a=
dvanced than just painting the CPPN output directly like in 
> > > > Picbre=
eder, just a fancy way of doing the same. 
> > > > 
> > > > Then I realized=
 that these "cells" can be also thought of an 
> > > > abstractions of "mas=
ses/groups of cells". In nature, cells 
don't 
> > just 
> > > > go "that w=
ay" moving through each other, but stick together. 
> > Entire 
> > > > tis=
sues develop fast as a mass of cells divides and increases 
> > size. So 
>=
 > > > I had this insight. I changed the concept of a cell and 
improved 
>=
 > over 
> > > > the previous model. A cell is a circle with a radius, has =
a 
color 
> > and 
> > > > has mass. It also has more properties but more o=
n that after a 
few 
> > > > other words. 
> > > > 
> > > > This is the key=
 idea. In my previous model, the CPPN was 
> > instructing a 
> > > > big m=
ass of many cells on the fly, during development time. It 
> > took 
> > > =
> advantage of using time as input, so the development was like 
a 
> > > >=
 spatial pattern in 4D. But it suffered from the coordinates 
and 
> > othe=
r 
> > > > problems I mentioned above. In this model, the CPPN does not 
> =
> operate 
> > > > on the cells during development. The CPPN predetermines =
the 
fate 
> > of 
> > > > each cell right in the egg, before development b=
egins. 
Everything 
> > else 
> > > > during development is a consequence o=
f the cell's fate and the 
> > > > internal 2D physics world in which the p=
henotype develops. So, 
in 
> > > > simpler words, the CPPN is programming =
the egg.
> > > > 
> > > > A cell has the following properties that are dete=
rmined by the 
> > CPPN:
> > > > - Color (of course :)
> > > > - Growth rat=
e. How fast it increases size in % of circle area. 
> > > > - Time to begin=
 growth. It is a value in [0 .. 1] where 1 is 
the 
> > total 
> > > > numb=
er of time steps allocated for development.
> > > > - Growth time duration.=
 Between some min and max value.
> > > > - Angle for division splitting. Be=
tween [-1 .. 1], during 
> > development 
> > > > rescaled to [0 .. pi]
> >=
 > > 
> > > > As cells grow, they will inevitably overlap each other. This =

issue 
> > is 
> > > > handled by the internal simple 2D physics engine th=
at adds 
forces 
> > if 
> > > > the circles overlap. So they eventually wi=
ll converge to a 
state 
> > that 
> > > > they only touch each other, and =
the whole phenotype bigger of 
> > course. 
> > > > Cells can divide. Divis=
ion is automatic. If a cell's radius 
> > reaches a 
> > > > a fixed tresho=
ld value, it is split into 2 cells, each one 
having 
> > > > exactly half =
the area of the mother cell. The mother cell is 
split 
> > > > along a pre=
determined angle, so the CPPN can control the 
overall 
> > > > directions =
of growth for the phenotype. The 2 children overlap 
in 
> > the 
> > > > b=
eginning, but as time progresses, they are pulled apart by 
the 
> > > > ph=
ysics. Children cells inherit the properties of the mother, 
but 
> > > > c=
hange their positions and reset their lifetime timers. The 
cells 
> > in 
=
> > > > the egg count their children and their grandchildren as well. 
No 
=
> > more 
> > > > than 3 generations of division can occur, in order to kee=
p the 
> > number 
> > > > of cells relatively small for performance consid=
erations. 
Though 
> > this 
> > > > value can be changed. 
> > > > 
> > > =
> In order to keep the phenotype solid, not torn apart from 
internal 
> > =
> > velocities, a mass-spring grid mesh is created in the egg 
before 
> > =
> > development. Cell divisions update the mesh. The mass-spring 
mesh 
> >=
 plus 
> > > > the cell-to-cell overlapping prevention forces act together =
as 
the 
> > > > phenotype increases in size and number of cells. Eventuall=
y it 
> > will 
> > > > become more stiff, where large group of recently di=
vided cells 
are 
> > > > packed together. I don't know if that is a bug or=
 a feature :) 
> > > > 
> > > > There is one insight I had after seeing the=
 results. Watching 
the 
> > mesh 
> > > > develops, and some with interest=
ing shapes and configurations, 
> > makes 
> > > > me think this approach i=
s very well suited to evolve HyperNEAT 
> > > > substrates as well. In fact=
 I am about to add brains to these 
> > > > creatures right this evening :)=
 But I don't know, if the links 
> > should 
> > > > be determined from the=
 beginning right in the egg or after 
> > > > development. Any suggestions?=
 
> > > > 
> > > > Well this is it. I hope this may be some advance into th=
e 
field. I 
> > > > will be happy to see any thoughts about this stuff. I'=
ll post 
an 
> > > > executable compiled with VS2008 in the files section n=
ow, so 
you 
> > will 
> > > > see it in action. Note however, that it is j=
ust a demo of 
> > development, 
> > > > not evolution. There is no doubt t=
hat this thing combined with 
> > NEAT 
> > > > will make at least somethin=
g very very cool. :) 
> > > > 
> > > > Peter
> > > >
> > >
> >
>
